channel.title: Bloomberg Economics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: How China’s Woes Resurrected the Economic Term ‘Involution’
item.description: Prolonged economic challenges tend to generate their own terminology. When the US struggled with low growth and below-target inflation in the years after the 2008 crisis, the oft-used phrase was “secular stagnation.” Even worse conditions in Japan gave rise to a “deflationary mindset.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: A BYD Co. Dynasty-D electric SUV on display at the Shanghai Auto Show in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. The event in the world's biggest automobile market will put a spotlight on some of China's most significant carmakers, including more recent entrants into the EV industry like Huawei and Xiaomi.

item.title: China Says Electric Vehicle Talks With EU Reach Final Stages
item.description: China’s commerce ministry said talks with the European Union on setting minimum prices for Chinese-made electric vehicles have “entered final stages,” although more work is required to reach a deal.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Lin Zhu

media:content.media:description: The launch event of the BYD Co. Dolphin Surf electric vehicle in Paris, France, on Wednesday, May 21, 2025. The launch of the Dolphin Surf, a fully-electric hatchback, will likely strengthen BYD’s foothold in Europe at a time when Chinese EV makers have been losing momentum on the continent.

item.title: Austria Cut to Record Low by Fitch as Budget Woes Persist
item.description: Austria’s sovereign credit was cut by Fitch Ratings to two steps below the top mark for the first time, handing the recently-formed government another setback in its bid to repair the country’s finances.
item.dc:creator: Marton Eder

media:content.media:description: Tourists and shoppers near the Sisi Museum in Vienna, Austria, on Thursday, Oct. 10, 2024. Austria's final consumer prices rose 1.8% year-over-year in September, according to Statistik Austria.

item.title: ECB’s Vujcic Says Interest-Rate Reductions Are Nearly Done
item.description: The European Central Bank’s interest-rate cutting campaign is almost over, Governing Council member Boris Vujcic said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Boris Vujcic, governor of the Croatian National Bank, during a Bloomberg Television interview at the Ten Years Of Euro In Latvia conference in Riga, Latvia on Friday, Jan. 26, 2024. The conference brings policy makers, experts and civil society representatives who played a pivotal role in the introduction of the euro all across Europe and specifically in Latvia.

item.title: Charting the Global Economy: ECB Nearing End of Rate-Cut Cycle
item.description: The European Central Bank is nearing the end of its campaign to lower interest rates after its eighth reduction in a year, according to ECB President Christine Lagarde.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle

item.title: Vietnam Inks Deals to Buy $3 Billion US Products Before Talks
item.description: Vietnamese businesses have signed 20 agreements worth about $3 billion to import more US agricultural products ahead of the third round of official negotiations set to take place next week.
item.dc:creator: Giang Nguyen

media:content.media:description: A worker uses a tractor to plant soybeans at Double G Angus Farms in Tiffin, Iowa, US, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Soybean futures posted the biggest intraday gain in more than three weeks on Wednesday after the US and China confirmed trade talks, lifting market sentiment over demand for American crop supplies. Photographer: Benjamin Roberts/Bloomberg

item.title: A Major American Egg Farm Just Lost 90% of its Chickens
item.description: Are egg prices going up again?
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: ISA Brown chickens in a chicken coop at an egg farm in Mason, Michigan, US, on Monday, March 3, 2025. Egg prices have soared to a record of over $8 a dozen, driven by the worst-ever outbreak of avian flu in the US and contributing to broader inflation pressures. Photographer: Emily Elconin/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan Won’t Wait for G-7 Summit for Possible US Trade Deal
item.description: Japan won’t necessarily wait for the Group of Seven Summit set to take place in Canada next week to seal a trade deal with the US if the two sides can agree earlier, Japan’s top negotiator Ryosei Akazawa said in Washington DC on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Akira Matsui, Yoshiaki Nohara, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa in Washington, DC, on June 6. Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea Says Trump Agrees to Ramp Up Tariff Talks With Lee
item.description: South Korea said newly elected President Lee Jae-myung spoke for the first time with Donald Trump and agreed to seek “tangible results” in trade negotiations, after the US leader imposed a 25% tariff on all imports from its Asian ally.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Sarina Yoo

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung at his inauguration in Seoul on June 4. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Pressures Fed’s Powell to Cut Rates ‘A Full Point’
item.description: President Donald Trump urged the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates by a full percentage point, intensifying his pressure campaign against Chair Jerome Powell.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Fabian, Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during the Federal Reserve IF 75TH Anniversary Conference in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, DC, US, on Monday, June 2, 2025. US President Donald Trump pushed Powell to lower interest rates at their first in-person meeting since the president's inauguration last week, the White House said.

item.title: Trump Says Xi to Restart Rare Earth Flows, Sets Date for Talks
item.description: President Donald Trump said his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping had agreed to restart the flow of rare-earth materials, as negotiators from the two nations prepare to resume trade talks on June 9 in London.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes at the Port of Los Angeles.

item.title: Finance Chief Signals That Colombia Will Suspend Fiscal Rule
item.description: Colombian Finance Minister German Avila signaled that the nation will suspend its fiscal anchor and also called for substantial interest rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Andreina Itriago, Matthew Bristow

item.title: Court Fight Over Trump Ending Tariff Exemption Goes Forward
item.description: A court fight over President Donald Trump’s decision to end a US policy that exempted small-value packages from China from tariffs is moving ahead over the administration’s opposition.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: Packages at a sorting center in Beijing.

item.title: Fed Appoints Michael Horowitz as New Inspector General
item.description: The US central bank appointed Michael E. Horowitz to head the Federal Reserve Board’s Office of Inspector General starting June 30.
item.dc:creator: Reade Pickert

media:content.media:description: Department of Justice Inspector General Michael Horowitz

item.title: Carney to Fast-Track ‘Nation-Building’ Projects Through Bill
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney announced legislation on Friday to fast-track “nation-building” projects in Canada and remove internal barriers to trade in an effort to shore up the country’s economy from the US tariff barrage.
item.dc:creator: Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney

item.title: Collapsing Immigration Makes US Jobs Data Harder to Read for Fed
item.description: A sharp decline in immigration is keeping a lid on the unemployment rate even as the economy slows.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva, Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: A construction worker frames a home at the Waterways subdivision in Gulf Shores, Alabama, US, on Friday, Dec. 6, 2024. US housing starts declined in October to the slowest pace in three months as hurricanes exacerbated an easing in construction activity more generally.

item.title: Fed’s Bowman Says Big Banks’ Secret Ratings Will Be Reviewed
item.description: Michelle Bowman, the Federal Reserve’s incoming vice chair for supervision, says the central bank will soon address the “odd mismatch” between the confidential ratings of big banks and the lenders’ financial conditions.
item.dc:creator: Katanga Johnson

media:content.media:description: Michelle Bowman, vice chair for supervision at the US Federal Reserve nominee for US President Donald Trump, during a Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee confirmation hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, April 10, 2025. Senators on both sides of the panel are likely to ask how Bowman plans to comply with an executive order that curbs the power of independent agencies, and are eager to hear how she will approach a plan that would require the country’s largest lenders to hold significantly more capital to buffer against losses and a financial crisis.

item.title: Tax-Hike Pressures to Follow UK Spending Review, Economists Say
item.description: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves is increasingly likely to have to raise taxes later this year as weak growth, higher borrowing costs and top-ups for public services put her fiscal rules at risk, economists warned.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves

item.title: What America’s Pizza Economy Is Telling Us About the Real One
item.description: Higher-end pies are still selling, but for lower-income consumers even frozen pizza is becoming a luxury.
item.dc:creator: Deena Shanker

media:content.media:description: Pizza Hut offers a large, single-topping pizza for $9.99, but most of its large pies cost at least twice that. Photographer: Jakub Porzycki/Getty Images

item.title: A Fed Official Goes Hunting for Inflation Clues in the Heartland
item.description: Faced with tariff uncertainty, policymakers are turning more to anecdotal information to guide their decisions.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee, right, during a tour of the locks and dam at Rock Island Arsenal along the Mississippi River, on June 2.

item.title: Trump Is Holding Back From Calling Out China Over Russia War Aid
item.description: President Donald Trump is holding back from pushing China to halt support for Russia’s war machine as he focuses on other issues in the relationship with its biggest geopolitical rival, according to US and European officials familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a meeting with Friedrich Merz, Germany's chancellor, not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. Relations between Washington and Berlin are tense amid issues ranging from trade imbalances to support for Kyiv.

item.title: Israel’s US Broker Sells Record Debt for Nation During Gaza War
item.description: Israel has raised a record $5 billion through its US-based broker dealer, Israel Bonds, since the start of the war with Hamas, boosting its ability to finance the 20-month ongoing conflict.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Israeli tanks near Israel's border with the Gaza Srip.

item.title: ECB Officials See Cuts Near End as Villeroy Hails ‘Victory’
item.description: The European Central Bank is approaching the end of its interest-rate cuts, according to two Governing Council members, as others declared inflation has been vanquished.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin, Joao Lima, Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: Madis Muller, deputy governor of Bank of Estonia (Eesti Pank), arrives for dinner during the Jackson Hole economic symposium, sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, in Moran, Wyoming, U.S., on Thursday, Aug. 23, 2018. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powells debut address to the Wyoming gathering of central bankers this week will do little to shake financial markets if history is any guide. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Indian Households See Inflation Staying Low, RBI Surveys Show
item.description: Indian households expect price pressures to stay low over the next 12 months, surveys by the Reserve Bank of India showed.
item.dc:creator: Prateek Mazumdar

media:content.media:description: Customers push their carts outside a supermarket in Mumbai, India, on Wednesday, March 25, 2020. India imposed a three-week long nationwide lockdown for its 1.3 billion people, the most far-reaching measure undertaken by any government to curb the spread of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Nabiullina Urges Caution After First Russian Rate Cut Since 2022
item.description: Russia’s central bank chief struck a circumspect tone on the path of monetary policy after lowering interest rates for the first time in nearly three years.
item.dc:creator: Greg Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Russia's central bank in Moscow.

item.title: US Jobs Report Points to Gradual Moderation in Labor Market
item.description: US job growth moderated in May and the prior months were revised lower, indicating employers are cautious about growth prospects as they weigh the Trump administration’s economic policy.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Employees scuff a door on the production line an assembly plant in Arlington, Texas. Photographer: Matthew Busch/Bloomberg

item.title: Here Are the Takeaways From the US Jobs Report for May
item.description: Here are five key takeaways from the US employment report for May, released Friday:
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran

media:content.media:description: A restaurant worker sets up an outdoor seating area in the Union Market district in Washington, DC. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Chile Annual Inflation Slows, Keeping Key Rate Cut on Table
item.description: Chile’s consumer prices rose in line with expectations on the month in May, while annual inflation unexpectedly edged down, keeping an interest rate cut in play at this month’s central bank meeting.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at a market in Santiago, Chile.

item.title: Canada Adds Just 8,800 Jobs, Unemployment Rises to 7%
item.description: The Canadian economy eked out minor job gains, and the unemployment rate rose for a third straight month to the highest level since September 2016 outside of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: Exhaust stacks at the Stellantis Windsor plant in Ontario. Since February, the labor market shed a net of 15,300 jobs as a result of firms slowing down hiring, downsizing or laying off due to US tariffs on Canadian auto, steel, aluminum and other sectors.

item.title: South African Lawmakers Agree Schedule to Process Third Budget
item.description: South African lawmakers will spend the coming weeks processing Finance Minister Enoch Godongwana’s third draft of the national budget after a dispute within the coalition government over taxes saw two previous versions scrapped.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vecchiatto, Michael Cohen

media:content.media:description: Enoch Godongwana, South Africa's finance minister, during the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank Spring meetings at the IMF headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. The International Monetary Fund sharply lowered its forecasts for world growth for this year and next, warning the outlook could deteriorate further as US President Donald Trump's tariffs spark a global trade war.
